dt: {bc}to squeeze or force by pressure so as to alter or destroy structure

dt.t: She {wi}crushed{/wi} her clothes into a bag.

dt: {bc}to reduce to particles by pounding or grinding
{bc}to suppress or overwhelm as if by pressure or weight

dt.t: She {wi}crushed{/wi} her child to her breast.

dt: {bc}to advance with or as if with {a_link|crushing}

dt.t: The crowd {wi}crushed{/wi} ruthlessly toward the exit.

dt: {bc}to experience an intense and usually passing infatuation {bc}to have a {d_link|crush|crush:2} on someone

dt.t: She's been {wi}crushing{/wi} on him all summer.
Turns out Fat Monica was motivated to lose all the weight after she overhead Chandler (whom she was {wi}crushing{/wi} on) tell Ross: "I don't want to be stuck here all night with your fat sister."

et: Middle English {it}crusshen{/it}, from Anglo-French {it}croissir, croistre{/it}, of Germanic origin; akin to Middle Low German {it}krossen{/it} to crush
shortdef: to squeeze or force by pressure so as to alter or destroy structure
to squeeze together into a mass
to reduce to particles by pounding or grinding

dt: {bc}a crowd of people pressing against one another

pt: {sc}crowd{/sc} {sc}throng{/sc} {sc}horde{/sc} {sc}crush{/sc} {sc}mob{/sc} mean an assembled multitude. {sc}crowd{/sc} implies a close gathering and pressing together.
{sc}crush{/sc} emphasizes the compactness of the group, the difficulty of individual movement, and the attendant discomfort.
{sc}mob{/sc} implies a disorderly crowd with the potential for violence.

shortdef: an intense and usually passing infatuation; also : the object of infatuation
crowd, mob; especially : a crowd of people pressing against one another

dt: {bc}romantic feelings felt by a schoolgirl or by someone who is being compared to a schoolgirl

shortdef: romantic feelings felt by a schoolgirl or by someone who is being compared to a schoolgirl
